A 35-year-old woman presents with recurrent, inflammatory dermal and subcutaneous infections characterized by granulomatous nodules on her legs. She has a history of minor trauma to the area while gardening. A fungal culture grows a dermatophyte known to cause deep dermal infections when introduced via cutaneous injury. Given her clinical presentation, which dermatophyte is most commonly associated with this type of granulomatous infection, often referred to as Majocchi's granuloma?

A clinical researcher is conducting a study on the thermal comfort of patients in a hospital ward. To evaluate the average temperature from all surfaces surrounding the patients, which instrument should the researcher use?

A 66-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of shortness of breath. His temperature is 37.2°C (99°F) and pulse is 105/min. When the blood pressure cuff is inflated to 140 mmHg, the patient's pulse is audible and regular. However, upon inspiration, the pulse disappears and does not reappear until expiration. Only when the blood pressure cuff is inflated to 125 mm Hg is the pulse audible throughout the entire respiratory cycle. Which of the following underlying conditions is most likely responsible for this patient's physical examination findings?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Asthma

 

  • The clinical finding described is pulsus paradoxus, a greater than normal (>10 mm Hg) drop in systolic blood pressure during inspiration.
  • Pulsus paradoxus occurs when the systolic blood pressure falls so much during inspiration that the peripheral pulse disappears with the blood pressure cuff inflated to a certain level.
  • The causes of pulsus paradoxus include asthma, pericardial tamponade, and severe obstructive airway diseases.
  • In asthma, increased negative intrathoracic pressure during inspiration exaggerates the normal inspiratory drop in blood pressure, causing pulsus paradoxus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mitral regurgitation: Does not cause pulsus paradoxus.

 

Option B. Lobar pneumonia: Usually causes fever and lung findings but not pulsus paradoxus.

 

Option C. Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy: Causes outflow obstruction but not pulsus paradoxus.

A 78-year-old male with severe chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) is admitted to the ICU with acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS). He is intubated and placed on mechanical ventilation. The treating physician decides to apply Positive End Expiratory Pressure (PEEP) to improve oxygenation. Following the adjustment, various physiological parameters are closely monitored to evaluate the effects of PEEP on the patient's respiratory and cardiovascular status. What is one of the effects of applying PEEP (Positive End Expiratory Pressure) in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Increased Functional Residual Capacity (FRC)

 

Positive End Expiratory Pressure (PEEP) is used in mechanically ventilated patients to prevent alveolar collapse at the end of expiration. It works by maintaining positive pressure within the alveoli during expiration, which:

 

  • Improves oxygenation by keeping alveoli open
  • Recruits collapsed alveoli, increasing the surface area for gas exchange
  • Increases the functional residual capacity (FRC) — the volume of air remaining in the lungs after passive expiration

 

An increase in FRC helps to reduce intrapulmonary shunting and improves the ventilation-perfusion (V/Q) mismatch, especially beneficial in conditions like ARDS.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Increased airway resistance: PEEP does not increase airway resistance. Airway resistance is more commonly influenced by bronchoconstriction, secretions, or endotracheal tube issues. PEEP works on alveolar pressure, not airway caliber.

 

Option C. Increase in cardiac output: PEEP increases intrathoracic pressure, which can reduce venous return to the heart, thereby decreasing cardiac output, especially at higher levels of PEEP.

 

Option D. Increased renal blood flow: PEEP can decrease renal perfusion due to reduced cardiac output and activation of neurohormonal responses (RAAS). This may lead to reduced urine output and fluid retention.

 

Educational Objective:


PEEP improves oxygenation in ventilated patients primarily by increasing functional residual capacity (FRC), which helps prevent alveolar collapse and improves ventilation-perfusion matching.

choices.text: Positive pressure ventilation with bag and mask

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of Step A in neonatal resuscitation?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Consider CPAP

 

  • In neonatal resuscitation, Step A is initiated when the baby has apnea, gasping, or heart rate <100 bpm. The recommended interventions in Step A include:
    • Positive Pressure Ventilation (PPV) using a bag and mask
    • SpO₂ monitoring to guide oxygen supplementation
    • ECG monitor placement for accurate heart rate measurement
  • CPAP (Continuous Positive Airway Pressure) is not indicated in apneic or gasping babies or those with bradycardia. Instead, CPAP is considered in babies who are breathing spontaneously but have labored breathing or persistent central cyanosis, which occurs in a different clinical context and not during Step A.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. PPV with bag and mask: Correct step — Initiated when HR <100 bpm or apnea/gasping is present.

 

Option C. SpO₂ monitoring: Correct — Used to monitor oxygenation and guide oxygen delivery during resuscitation.

 

Option D. Consider ECG monitor: Correct — Helps in rapid and accurate heart rate assessment.

 

Educational Objective:
 

  • Step A in neonatal resuscitation involves initiating PPV, monitoring oxygenation, and assessing heart rate using ECG. 
  • CPAP is not a part of Step A; it is reserved for neonates who are breathing but have labored respirations or persistent cyanosis.

questions.text:
A 43-year-old woman with borderline personality disorder is brought to the emergency department after taking an undetermined number of pills. She is lethargic but arousable. She refuses to answer questions. Blood pressure is 110/60 mmHg and heart rate is 120/min and regular. Laboratory results are as follows:

 

Sodium: 139 mEg/L

 

Potassium: 3.3 mEq/L

 

Chloride : 98 mEq/L

 

Bicarbonate: 13 mEq/L

 

Arterial blood gases on room air

 

pH: 7.46

 

PaCO2: 19 mmHg

 

PaO2: 96 mmHg

 

Oxygen saturation: 99%

 

Which of the following best describes this patient's acid-base disturbance?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Metabolic acidosis and respiratory alkalosis

 

  • Low bicarb = metabolic acidosis, low CO2 = concurrent respiratory alkalosis → mixed disorder.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Acidosis + alkalosis (metabolic both) → Not fitting.

 

Option B. Respiratory acidosis → PaCO2 is low, so incorrect.

 

Option D. Metabolic alkalosis → Not consistent with HCO3 13.

A 12-year-old boy with three lesions and one nerve involved
A 34-year-old female presenting with four hypopigmented anesthetic skin patches

questions.text: A woman is prescribed rifampicin monthly, dapsone daily, and clofazimine monthly and daily for 6 months. According to the WHO leprosy regimen, what clinical profile does she most likely have?
questions.solution: Ans. C) A 34-year-old female presenting with four hypopigmented anesthetic skin patches

questions.text: A patient has a visual acuity of less than 3/60 in the right eye and the perception of light in the left eye. In terms of visual impairment categories, to which category does this individual belong?

choices.text: There is abnormal umbilical artery Doppler

questions.text: A 38-week primigravida presents with decreased fetal movements. A modified biophysical profile (mBPP) is performed, and the non-stress test (NST) is reactive. The second component of the test, as shown in the ultrasound images, involves measuring the amniotic fluid index (AFI). What is your inference?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) There is oligohydramnios

 

  • Amniotic Fluid Index (AFI) is measured by summing the vertical pockets of amniotic fluid in the four quadrants of the uterus on ultrasound.

 

AFI Interpretation:

 

  • Normal: 5-25 cm
  • Oligohydramnios: AFI < 5 cm
  • Polyhydramnios: AFI > 25 cm

 

In this case, AFI = 0 + 1.2 + 1.6 + 2.2 = 4.9 cm, which is oligohydramnios.

 

Oligohydramnios is an indication for delivery in a term pregnancy, as it suggests uteroplacental insufficiency.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It is normal: Incorrect. AFI of less than 5 cm is considered oligohydramnios.

 

Option C. There is fetal hypoxia: Incorrect. Oligohydramnios itself does not confirm hypoxia. A reactive NST suggests adequate fetal oxygenation.

 

Option D. There is abnormal umbilical artery Doppler: Incorrect. Umbilical artery Doppler is not assessed in a modified BPP. While oligohydramnios can be associated with abnormal Doppler findings, it is not diagnostic of abnormal umbilical artery flow.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Take the last missed pill as soon as possible and continue the remaining packet
Take the missed pill as soon as possible and offer her emergency contraception
Take the missed pill as soon as possible and use additional contraception for 7 days
Take the missed pill as soon as possible, use emergency contraception, and discard the remaining packet

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman presents to the family planning outpatient department on Day 8 of her menstrual cycle with concerns that she missed two doses of her oral contraceptive pills (OCPs) on Days 7 and 8. She has been taking OCPs regularly for the past two years. She has no history of unprotected intercourse during the missed days. What is the most appropriate advice for her?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Take the last missed pill as soon as possible and continue the remaining packet

 

  • This patient missed two consecutive doses of her OCPs during Week 1 of her cycle. According to OCP guidelines:
  • If a woman misses one or two pills:
    • She should take the last missed pill as soon as possible (i.e., take two pills together: Day 7 and Day 8).
    • She should continue the remaining pills as scheduled.
    • No additional contraception is necessary, as long as she resumes taking the pills regularly.
  • Emergency contraception is not required unless she has had unprotected intercourse in the past 5 days, which she denies.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Take the missed pill as soon as possible and offer her emergency contraception: Incorrect. Emergency contraception is not necessary for missing only two pills unless unprotected intercourse occurred during the missed days.

 

Option C. Take the missed pill as soon as possible and use additional contraception for 7 days: Incorrect. Additional contraception (e.g., condoms) is only needed if three or more pills are missed or if she had unprotected intercourse while missing the pills.

 

Option D. Take the missed pill as soon as possible, use emergency contraception, and discard the remaining packet: Incorrect. The patient should not discard the packet. She should resume the pills immediately, and emergency contraception is unnecessary unless unprotected intercourse occurred.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • For women who miss one or two OCPs, they should take the missed pills immediately and continue the regular dosing schedule. Additional contraception is not needed unless three or more pills are missed, or unprotected intercourse occurred during the missed days.

Which of the following is used to monitor PCM (paracetamol) toxicity?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Rumack Matthew

 

The Rumack-Matthew nomogram is used to assess risk of hepatotoxicity after acute paracetamol overdose based on plasma concentration vs time.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Matzke: Used for aminoglycoside dosing.

 

Option C. Hartford: Not relevant for paracetamol.

 

Option D. Naranjo: Adverse drug reaction probability scale.

questions.text: A 35-year-old female presents with complaints of worsening peripheral vision. An ophthalmologic examination shows loss of visual fields in the temporal region. An MRI of the brain is shown below. Laboratory investigations reveal the following hormone levels: Prolactin: 52 ng/mL (normal range: 4 to 23 ng/mL), ACTH: 9 pg/mL (normal range: 10 to 60 pg/mL), TSH: 0.1 mIU/mL (normal range: 0.4 to 4.0 mIU/mL), GH: 1 ng/mL (normal range: <5 ng/mL). What is the most likely diagnosis?

A forensic examiner is presented with a set of preserved clothing articles from a case that is 4 months old. Suspicion arises regarding the presence of aged seminal stains on the fabric. Which of the following biochemical tests should the examiner prioritize to yield reliable results for detection of seminal stain?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Creatine phosphokinase (CPK) test

 

  • Spermatozoa contain a high concentration of CPK, which is more than double, than found in any other body fluid. 
  • The enzyme is stable and can be demonstrated even in old stains of six months, making it an effective tool for confirming the presence of semen in stains.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acid phosphatase test:  It is very useful test for recent stains as concentration of acid phosphatase is very high in seminal fluid. However, the concentration of acid phosphatase gradually falls with time, with gradual disappearance in 72 hours. So it is not good for old stains 

 

Option B. Barberio test: Detects spermine from the prostate in the seminal fluid, which is characterized by the formation of yellow needle-shaped rhombic crystals (spermine picrate). It is a presumptive test for seminal stain, not very reliable.

 

Option C. Florence test: Florence test is indicative of the presence of choline from seminal vesicles and results in dark brown rhombic crystals of choline iodide upon treatment with Florence reagent. It is a presumptive test for seminal stain, not very reliable

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Florence test—Not a reliable test. For choline (dark brown rhombic crystals)
  • Barberio test— Detects spermine (yellow needle-shaped rhombic crystals)
  • Acid phosphatase test—Conclusive test in absence of sperm
  • Creatine phosphokinase—Helpful in old seminal stain

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl presents to the clinic with primary amenorrhea. She reports no breast development but has not experienced menarche. questions.text: Which of the following markers will be positive in the following patient?
In the classification of dengue severity, which of the following is not categorized under “warning signs”?

Identify the correct statements

 

  1. Macula densa is located at the Junction of thick ascending limb and DCT
  2. The organ with the least arteriovenous pressure difference is the kidney.
  3. Massive splenomegaly is noted in hairy cell leukaemia, CML and aplastic anemia
  4. Lipofuschin is intranuclear, peri-lysosomal in location.
The flow volume curve after spirometry in patient 1 is given below. The most likely diagnosis in this patient is:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Morbid obesity

 

Morbid obesity causes a restrictive pattern on spirometry characterized by reduced lung volumes with preserved flow rates, resulting in a flow-volume curve with decreased volumes but relatively normal shape, consistent with restriction rather than obstruction.

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. Vocal cord palsy: Typically produces variable extrathoracic obstruction with flattening of the inspiratory limb on flow-volume curve.

 

Option B. Bronchial asthma: Shows obstructive pattern with reduced expiratory flow and scooped-out appearance of the curve.

 

Option D. Emphysema: An obstructive pattern characterized by reduced flow rates and increased lung volumes with a concave expiratory limb.

questions.text: In a 14-day triple-drug therapy for H. pylori, how much amoxicillin is prescribed daily?
A 55 year old male with difficulty in urinary stream also presented with back ache. A CT was done. What is the likely diagnosis?
A 60-year-old man with BPH presents with acute urinary retention. Which is the most appropriate next step?

choices.text: 10% of the normal population can have epileptiform discharges.
Scalp EEG may be helpful in localizing frontal lobe epilepsy.
Doing EEG is not mandatory for the diagnosis of seizures.
Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy shows triphasic and slow waves.

questions.text: True about electroencephalogram (EEG) is all except:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 10% of the normal population can have epileptiform discharges.

 

  •  Only about 1% of healthy individuals may show epileptiform discharges; 10% is an overestimation, hence incorrect.

 

Opter Options:

 

Option B. Scalp EEG may be helpful in localizing frontal lobe epilepsy: True, though sometimes challenging due to deep seizure foci, scalp EEG can still provide useful localization.


Option C. Doing EEG is not mandatory for the diagnosis of seizures: Correct, seizures are primarily a clinical diagnosis; EEG supports but is not always required.


Option D. Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy shows triphasic and slow waves: True, diffuse slowing and triphasic waves can be seen in metabolic and infectious encephalopathies like PML.

questions.text:
What would be seen if the central part of the cord was involved? 

 

  1. LMN lesion of trunk and UMN of lower limbs.
  2. UMN lesion of trunk and LMN of lower limbs.
  3. Bladder and bowel involvement.
  4. Posterior tract involvement.
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1 and 3

 

  •  Central cord lesions typically damage gray matter at the level of the lesion → LMN signs at that level (eg, trunk/upper limb weakness) and may also compress descending tracts → UMN signs in lower limbs. As the lesion progresses centrally, bladder & bowel involvement is common.

 

1 (LMN trunk + UMN lower limbs): Correct, due to segmental LMN loss and long tract UMN involvement.


3 (Bladder and bowel involvement): Correct, central cord compression can disrupt autonomic pathways.

 

Incorrect statements:

 

2 (UMN trunk + LMN lower limbs): Not seen; UMN signs don’t occur at the lesion level.

4 (Posterior tract involvement): Typically spared in central lesions until very advanced, so not a defining feature.

questions.text:
Which of the following types of headaches requires further evaluation? 

 

  1. Duration > 4 hours
  2. Thunderclap nature 
  3. Associated Low GCS 
  4. Associated Blurring of vision
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 2, 3, 4

 

Red flag features in headaches that warrant urgent evaluation include:

 

2. Thunderclap headache → sudden, severe onset, may suggest subarachnoid hemorrhage.

 

3. Altered consciousness / low GCS → indicates raised intracranial pressure, hemorrhage, infection, or mass lesion.

 

4. Blurring of vision → could indicate raised ICP, papilledema, or secondary pathology.

 

Incorrect statements:

 

1. Duration > 4 hours → common in migraines, tension headaches, etc., but not by itself a red flag unless associated with other features.

questions.text: Identify the stage of sleep based on the EEG shown below:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) REM

 

The EEG and polysomnogram pattern shown is characteristic of REM sleep.

Key Features in the Image

  • EEG: Shows low amplitude, mixed frequency waves—resembling awake state.
  • EOG (electro-oculogram): Shows rapid eye movements.
  • EMG (electromyogram): Shows muscle atonia (almost flat line).
  • ECG: Regular cardiac rhythm.
  • REM sleep is identified by rapid eye movements, low-amplitude, mixed-frequency EEG, and absent muscle tone (EMG atonia).

 

Opter Options:

 

Option A. NREM1: Light sleep with theta waves.

 

Option B. NREM2: Sleep spindles and K-complexes.

 

Option C. NREM3: Deep sleep with delta waves.

 

Only REM sleep combines flattened EMG, rapid eye movements, and low-voltage EEG.

questions.text: Among the following enzymes, which one does not participate in the reversible phase of the pentose phosphate pathway?
A 3-year-old child is brought to the casualty with a history of choking over a peanut. The child suddenly becomes unresponsive. What would you do as the next step of management?

23-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by her boyfriend 10 minutes after ingesting at least 15 acetaminophen tablets. She has been admitted to the hospital several times in the past few months after attempted self-harm. She claims that her boyfriend is " extremely selfish" and "does not care for her." She says she feels lonely and wants her boyfriend to pay attention to her. Her boyfriend says that they have broken up 10 times in the past year because she is prone to outbursts of physical aggression as well as mood swings. He says that these mood swings last a few hours and can vary from states of "exuberance and affection” to states of "depression." On examination, the patient appears well-dressed and calm. She has normal speech, thought processes, and thought content. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

Research is being conducted to assess the nutritional status of the children in a particular district. For this purpose, 2 children are randomly selected from every school in the district. What is this type of sampling known as?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Cluster

 

Schools act as clusters, and children are sampled within them. This reduces cost and logistics in large populations and is a standard method for community health surveys.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Simple random: requires selecting children directly from the whole district, not grouped by schools.

 

Option B. Systematic random: involves fixed intervals (e.g., every 5th child), not cluster-based.

 

Option C. Stratified random: divides population into strata (e.g., age or gender groups) before random selection, unlike clustering by schools.
